body: Looking Ahead ADAM PERRY LANG AND JAMIE OLIVER Adam Perry Lang, left, the chef and a partner in Daisy May's BBQ USA, and Jamie Oliver, the English celebrity chef, have teamed up with deep-pocketed backers to open a chain of restaurants. There is no name yet, but the first restaurant is to be in Dublin, with openings planned for Berlin, Cape Town
title: Off the Menu

body: Sunday morning was a nasty time to be out and about in New York, with cold rain falling hard, but the predawn hours were worse. Sleet was blowing at just the right angle to find its way into tightly drawn hoods and mittens, and yet 17 people got out of bed anyway, all with the same thought: ''I shall go stand in the middle of an intersection in
title: A Solstice Tribute, Shorter Than the Day Is Long

body: WHEN I went into labor this fall, my daughter was three weeks early. But my kitchen renovation was running five weeks late. I had carefully planned that the two events would not overlap, but there I was listening to the screech of the drill in between contractions while my husband, Daniel, dashed around the bedroom packing the hospital bag. I moved
title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK; Tossing a Rattle Into the Renovation

body: CROWN HEIGHTS, Brooklyn, a mash-up of cultures, is home to both the annual West Indian American parade and the headquarters of the Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidim. Adding an upscale bar and beer garden to the mix might seem counterintuitive. ''Everyone thought we were crazy,'' said Anatoly Dubinsky, recalling the reaction last April when he opened
title: BOÃŽTE; An Already Eclectic Mix Gets an Upscale Bar

body: WHEN the flight from Heathrow landed at Kennedy Airport, the cabin quickly filled with the sounds of seat belts being unfastened, cellphones beeping and passengers grabbing their overhead luggage. Taking a deep breath, Njoya Hilary Tikum joined the crush of people waiting to exit. Mr. Tikum, who was 26 and had a compact build and a broad, handsome
title: The Years of Living Nervously

body: SOME New Yorkers never get to know their neighbors. They nod hello, but rarely speak, and they certainly don't break bread with them. Even names may remain a mystery, unless an errant letter finds its way into the wrong mailbox. This is precisely the New York that a group of Brooklyn residents hopes to escape. They plan to do so by pooling their
title: A Village Down the Block

body: THE Blue Marble ice cream shop, on Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, has been open for just over a year, and it took only seven months for its owners -- first-time businesswomen -- to open their second store, in Prospect Heights. For their next venture, they have in mind a location slightly more ambitious: Kigali, Rwanda. The improbable
title: BOERUM HILL; A Taste of Hope For a Tragic Land

body: A MATTER Of Principle Waiting in a drab hallway of a Lower Manhattan courthouse, Kimber VanRy got a bit of unsolicited advice from a Brooklyn auto mechanic who had just agreed to pay $15 for violating, as Mr. VanRy is accused of doing, the city's open-container law. ''If I was you, I would have pled guilty and paid the $15,'' the mechanic said.
title: CITY ROOM; A Matter of Principle

body: Four minutes into their first home game on Saturday night, the Brooklyn Aces of the Eastern Professional Hockey League began defending their frozen turf on Flatbush Avenue. Jerry Cardinale, one of Brooklyn's own, squared off at center ice with Teague Willits-Kelley of the Jersey Rockhoppers. As both players tossed their helmets and gloves to the
title: Watch Out for That Stick, Er, Fist: Professional Ice Hockey Bursts Into Brooklyn

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, Barack Obama became the first African-American to be elected president of the United States. The dream of racial equality that Dr. King so eloquently described at the March on Washington has seemingly come
title: Spare Times

body: THESE days, when you find a chef with the urge to tinker, he will most likely be embroiled in such delicate work as teasing out the covalent bonds of mayonnaise or synthesizing panko gelatin. But what about the rougher breeds of food geek, those who, if not for a culinary passion, would have wound up in their yard, building rockets out of scrap
title: Pizza From Scratch: First, Get Bricks and a Trailer

body: New York Comedy Festival With a few exceptions, the lineup at the fifth annual New York Comedy Festival is not inherently political. But the festival begins on Wednesday, the day after the election that has been the source of punch lines, gaffes and punditry-defining impressions for more than a year. No matter who wins, will the comedians -- who
title: Spare Times

body: A Serbian basketball player who fled the United States after a bar brawl in upstate New York that left a fellow student, from Brooklyn, in a coma, was arrested on Tuesday in Belgrade, the police said. The Serbian student, Miladin Kovacevic, 21, was detained on suspicion that he had ''inflicted severe bodily harm'' on the other student, Bryan
title: Ex-SUNY Basketball Player Arrested After Fleeing to Serbia

body: THE urge, at times, can be almost overwhelming: Ahmad Batebi will be walking down a New York street, engrossed in some serious business, and he will spot a basketball game. In that moment, he wants more than anything to join in. In the next, he feels a pang of regret for seeming childish. Sometimes, he says, he feels that he has left himself
title: DISPATCHES; A Torchbearer, Then and Now

body: 'BOO AT THE ZOO' You can do so much with pumpkins this season: cook them for soups and desserts, carve them into jack-o'-lanterns, decorate them for your stoop, even give them to your cats as toys -- that is, if you have really, really big cats. The Bronx Zoo does, and giving its creatures pumpkins (above, a black leopard) is one of the high points
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: FOR CHILDREN 'ADVENTURES OF THE PUPPET PRINCESS' (Saturday and Sunday) Can a puppet show really mollify a witch? That's the issue in this new production from the Looking Glass Theater, which draws on Balinese puppetry, masks and folklore. Written and directed by Jennifer Goodlander, the show focuses on Putu, a tomboy, who is lost in the jungle with
title: Spare Times

body: NOT long ago, the hipsters of Brooklyn looked down their pierced noses on Prospect Heights, a sleepy neighborhood of brownstones and tree-lined streets just north of Prospect Park. While the area had a diverse mix of white, African-American and West Indian residents, there was little beside Caribbean takeout joints and hole-in-the-wall barbershops
title: SURFACING; Adding to the Mix in Brooklyn

body: 36 HOURS IN NEW YORK From a burger brunch in Hell's Kitchen to fancy cocktails in Brooklyn, Seth Kugel spends a weekend exploring the city's newest offerings in a video. FRUGAL NEW YORK Follow Matt Gross on a video tour as he becomes a frugal tourist in his own city, taking subways between free museums and cheap curries. SURFACING: PROSPECT HEIGHTS
title: THIS WEEK ON THE WEB

body: THE 2009 Michelin and Zagat guides to New York restaurants were published yesterday, and though their reviewing and rating methods are completely different, Zagat and Michelin tend to like the same places -- for the most part. In Michelin, the highest score is three stars, determined by anonymous professional inspectors. For 2009 it ranked 563
title: Masa and Mas Win In New Food Guides

body: FOR years, Adam Frank yearned for a brownstone of his own. In 2002, after living in a series of rentals in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, he almost bought one for $575,000. It was a three-family brownstone on South Second Street. ''It was in need of a major overhaul,'' he said. After the inspection, ''I freaked out and had trouble getting financing. I was
title: THE HUNT; A 'Goldilocks' House

body: A small-business owner in Brooklyn worries about making the payroll. A homeowner in Queens faces foreclosure. A suburban stay-at-home mother cuts back on luxuries. A retiree watches rent, food and cable bills rise while her income stays flat. An aspiring musician chooses between recording fees and a trip to see his family at Christmas. A head of a
title: Six Tales of Perseverance, and Futility, in the Eye of a Fiscal Storm

body: In March, New York City enacted a law making it illegal for landlords to discriminate against tenants who planned to use federal subsidies known as Section 8 vouchers to help pay their rent. But Section 8 discrimination remains a widespread problem, housing advocates, tenant lawyers and voucher holders say. Renters are routinely turned away by
title: Despite New Law, Subsidized Tenants Find Doors Closed

body: MANY people have had an indirect hand in the small, sweet new restaurant James, starting with James Calvert, for whom it's named. A great-grandfather of the restaurant's chef, Bryan Calvert, he too made his living as a cook in New York, setting an example, showing the way. The list goes on to include the writer Susan Sontag, who died in 2004, and
title: RESTAURANTS; In the Neighborhood, and of It

body: International NATO TIGHTENS RULES To Lower Afghan Casualties Gen. David D. McKiernan, the top American military commander in Afghanistan, said he had tightened the rules on when NATO troops can use lethal force, in an effort to lower civilian casualties there. General McKiernan also said that the military mission in Afghanistan still needed
title: Inside the Times, September 17, 2008

body: IN New York, anything is possible. On a good day, you can meet the woman of your dreams in a crowded elevator, or reclaim your long-lost dignity by telling off that bully in the packed subway car during rush hour. You can eat a hot dog every five blocks, or catch a midnight showing of ''The Manchurian Candidate.'' You can be a college dropout and
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Grand Central Apartment

body: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the alternatives to New York City Opera performances misidentified the Brooklyn neighborhood of Freddy's Bar and Backroom, which features Opera on Tap, a collection of singers who perform arias and duets in bars. It is in Prospect Heights, not Williamsburg.
title: Correction

body: MOST teenage girls love to talk to their friends. And talk. And talk. As Debra Lee, the Brooklyn mother of a 13-year-old, observes about her daughter Tessa and Tessa's teenage friends: ''They just keep talking. All day. On the phone all night. Sometimes I think they just like to hear each other breathe.'' Virginia Woolf said, ''Some people go to
title: Girl Talk Has Its Limits

body: Kimber VanRy was sitting on his stoop in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn, drinking a beer and sending e-mail messages on his BlackBerry, when a police car slowed to a stop on the street in front of him. It had been a pleasant evening for Mr. VanRy, 39, who lives in a four-story, 20-unit co-op building with his wife and two children. He had
title: Fighting for the Right to Drink Beer on His Stoop

author: Alice Mattison's latest novel, ''Nothing Is Quite Forgotten in Brooklyn,'' will be published this month by Harper Perennial.
body: ''GO one stop on the express, change for the local and get on at the back of the train.'' My father knew how to take the subway almost anywhere, and he'd even instruct you where to stand on the platform so as to be near the most convenient exit when you got off. But going from one place in Brooklyn to another was beyond even him. When I was a
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Along the Tracks of Her Mind

body: THE big news in classical music this fall is what won't be: a real season for New York City Opera. The company is essentially shutting down during renovations to its New York State Theater home, offering two unstaged performances of ''Antony and Cleopatra'' at Carnegie Hall in January and several fistfuls of orchestra concerts and lectures. That
title: No City Opera? Try Some Alternatives

body: FROM a seat near the center of Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn one recent sunny afternoon, the world was a surprisingly quiet place. The sounds of the traffic whirlpool swirling around in every direction had receded into a white-noise drone, and the only pedestrian passers-by were those brave enough to cross four lanes of cars at one time in pursuit
title: DISPATCHES; In the Heart of Brooklyn, No Man's Island

body: DURING his freshman year at Point Park University in Pittsburgh a couple years ago, James Acklin, now 20, felt lost among the social cliques on his new campus until he got to talking with a student who was in some of his classes. She seemed unusual, and it wasn't just her look: thick-framed eyeglasses, bangs and vintage dresses. Then, one rainy day
title: Another Spin for Vinyl

body: IT'S hard to miss the sprinkling of ''Hot Bird'' signs visible from Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. Aside from what could be considered the jarring juxtaposition of the words ''hot'' and ''bird,'' a few of the signs are painted a radiant yellow and are bigger than highway billboards. For more than a decade, the signs have made vegetarians wince and
title: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; On Teasing Walls, Traces of Roasters Past

author: E-mail: greenfield@nytimes.com
body: SIX years ago, Yvette Folk made a real estate purchase that not everyone in her life could see the value in. ''My sister called my father to say that I had lost my mind,'' said Ms. Folk, 52, describing the offending apartment: a one-bedroom co-op in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, on Albemarle Road. The property had sat vacant for two years after the owner
title: THE SELL; When It's Not Enough Just to Cut the Price

body: THEY can be seen all along Atlantic Avenue -- urban foragers of a sort, often bedraggled and always in search of a dollar. Many of them pump gas, but that is not the only hustle along the strip. As one regular walks on sections of Atlantic, a traffic-clogged 10-mile road that runs from the Brooklyn waterfront to the Van Wyck Expressway in western
title: Hard Times Along Gasoline Alley

body: COULD Champagne replace beer as Brooklyn's quaff of choice? Now there's fighting words. But bartenders in this venerably beery borough seem, increasingly, to be reaching for a heavy-bottomed bottle of Champagne, rather than a long-necked bottle of beer. Not that they're pouring it, unaccompanied, into delicate flutes -- Brooklyn's gentrification
title: SHAKEN AND STIRRED; Well, It's Not Champale

body: HANGING on a wall at James, a new restaurant in the ground floor of an apartment building in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is a captivating painting of a nattily dressed man whose dark eyes seem to be watching the diners. His swept-back hair, pale complexion and handlebar mustache suggest a turn-of-the-last-century British provenance, as does the
title: PROSPECT HEIGHTS; Serve Well. An Ancestor Is Watching.

body: Paul Spencer Byard, a land-use lawyer who returned to school in his late 30s to be an architect and who became an important figure in the renovation of some of New York's most prominent landmarks, died on Tuesday at his home in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. He was 68. The cause was cancer, said Charles A. Platt, a partner of Mr. Byard's in Platt
title: Paul Byard, 68, Dies; Architect Renovated Landmarks

body: At Newswalk, a 168-unit condominium building in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, doormen have for years let residents know they have packages by putting little yellow sticky notes on their mailboxes. They still do that, but now many residents receive automated phone calls or e-mail alerts, too. ''At first, I thought the calls were spam,'' said James
title: For Half a Cent, a Call That Informs, and Annoys

author: Compiled by Kris Ensminger E-mail: eating@nytimes.com
body: Prospect Heights is among the city's smaller neighborhoods, but it is home to numerous attractions (the Brooklyn Public Library, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the Brooklyn Museum) and to a vibrant dining scene. There is room for the Garden Cafe, a tiny institution since 1986, and for James, a promising restaurant that opened last month. Abigail
title: GOOD EATING | PROSPECT HEIGHTS; A Tasty Density

body: THOUGH the moon was just a crescent and the monsoons were far away, Burmese Buddhists from around New York came last Sunday to the Universal Peace Buddha Temple complex, a four-story building on Bergen Street in Prospect Heights that is painted maroon like a monk's robe. They gathered to observe the full-moon day of Waso, a holy day during the
title: PROSPECT HEIGHTS; Even in Brooklyn, Signs of the Monsoon

body: MOHAMMED ALI shares his name with a legend, never saw his future wife during the first seven years of their courtship, and didn't start to work seriously on his writing until he already had his first book contract. But given prices in Brooklyn these days, the truly startling part of his story is that his two-bedroom Prospect Heights apartment, with
title: HABITATS | PROSPECT HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; Growing Into a Home, and a Country

body: ON most summer Sundays, Brooklyn is burning. Smoke rises from grills, many of them charcoal-fueled, illegal and loaded with jerk chicken -- the spiced, smoky favorite of the borough's large Jamaican community. ''We don't mess around out here,'' said Hubert Lawton, an owner of Boston Jerk City in East Flatbush, where an oil drum full of charcoal
title: Sweet Heat: For Jamaicans, It's About Jerk

body: Ronnie Mathews, a jazz pianist whose recorded output as a leader was sparse but whose rÃ©sumÃ© as a sideman with stars of jazz was substantial, died on Saturday in Brooklyn. He was 72 and lived in the Prospect Heights neighborhood. The cause was pancreatic cancer, his daughter, Salima Millott, said. Mr. Matthews spent most of his career out of the
title: Ronnie Mathews, 72, Pianist; Accompanied Jazz Stars

body: The United States ambassador to Serbia on Tuesday demanded the arrest and return of a Serbian-born college basketball player who fled this country after being charged with beating a classmate into a coma in a barroom dispute in Binghamton, N.Y. Officials said the demand was made by the ambassador, Cameron Munter, who said in a statement that he had
title: U.S. Ambassador Demands Return of Serb Over Beating

body: Opening this Week ALLORO Salvatore Corea, a native of Calabria who owns Bocca and Cacio e Pepe in New York, has added this spot, which he owns with his wife, Gina. It opened yesterday. His menu takes sensible liberties with Italian classics, like buffalo mozzarella with tomato tartare: 307 East 77th Street, (212) 535-2866. JAMES Seasonal American
title: Off the Menu

body: EVER since 2003, when a leggy Muslim girl from Senegal named Hawa Kebe immigrated to Brooklyn, in the eighth grade, she has dreamed of going to her senior prom. So in the late fall, when she learned that her high school wasn't planning a prom, she volunteered to organize one. Never mind that many of Hawa's classmates at the International High
title: This Strange Thing Called Prom

body: Say you are given a choice of two cookies. One is made with butter, the other with partially hydrogenated vegetable oil. Both have the same amount of calories from fat. Which do you choose? If you picked the butter cookie, you can keep eating. But the one made with P.H.V.O., as it is known in the trade, is forbidden come July 1, when the final
title: Restaurants Prepare For Big Switch: No Trans Fat

body: This year, the International High School in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn is graduating its first senior class. The seniors, who come from far-flung places, are going to the prom, and many of them are having their first brush with this classically American rite of passage. nytimes.com/thecity
title: A PROM FOR ALL NATIONS

body: WHILE condominium developers across the country are trying to unload thousands of apartments that they can't sell, some builders in Brooklyn have found the real estate equivalent of a golden parachute. Having turned their new units into high-priced rentals, they have found a surprising number of eager takers. These renters are a breed of
title: They (The New) Brooklyn

body: George Leonard, the principal of the Bedford Academy High School in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, used to take a straightforward approach to ensuring that students at the school he founded showed up for after-school tutoring when he or their teachers thought they needed it. ''We'd block the exits,'' Mr. Leonard said. His background as a star
title: BIG CITY; A School Succeeds With Extra Study and Little Homework

body: Linda Wu said that whenever troubles in Myanmar make news in the United States, business spikes at the two Burmese restaurants she owns in Manhattan, with regular patrons coming by daily to check on her and the restaurants' staff. And once the regulars check in, Ms. Wu said, most of them stay to eat. That's how it was in September, when Myanmar's
title: Fearing for Many at Home, City's Burmese Unite To Aid Cyclone Victims

title: Spare Times

title: ON EDUCATION; Failings of One Brooklyn High School May Threaten a Neighbor's Success

body: IN the real estate market, outdoor space is gold. It's expensive, it's rare, and it can add enormous value to a home. title: The High Life

title: Taking The Pulse Of the Boroughs

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; The Tragically Hip, and Civic Hard Times

title: Spare Times: For Children

body: FOR CHILDREN 'JUNIE B. JONES' Here's a young heroine who inspires immediate sympathy. Entering a new grade, Junie B. Jones discovers that her closest pal, Lucille, has become the ''new best friend'' of snooty twins. body: The slowing economy, weighed down by a widening credit crisis, is likely to delay the signature office tower and three residential buildings at the heart of the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, the developer said. title: Slow Economy Likely to Stall Atlantic Yards

title: THE HUNT; Taking the Two-Family Path

body: The body of a Brooklyn man who had been stabbed in the side of the head with a corkscrew was discovered by relatives in his Prospect Heights apartment on Wednesday, the police said on Thursday. The man, Murat St. Hilaire, 55, was declared dead at the scene. He was found lying face up on the bedroom floor of Apartment 1B at 594 Park Place at 6:15
title: Man Fatally Stabbed With Corkscrew

body: For Ronald K. Brown, the choreographer and dancer who formed Evidence Dance Company in 1985 at 19, evidence is a twin concept. Part of it is spiritual faith, evidence of things unseen, and part is physical movement used in telling stories from the African diaspora, evidence of endurance, suffering and triumph. Outside the dance world Mr. Brown is
title: Making Rich Tales Of Diaspora Take Flight

body: I RECENTLY went into Manhattan with a friend to visit her younger brother's new apartment on 52nd Street and the East River. His two roommates had followed the same path, and so, apparently, had everyone else who lived on their long,
title: His City, Lost and Found

title: New York's Newest Citizens Hungry to Cast Their Votes

body: Dibs on a Junker Q. There's an older BMW parked near my home in Jackson Heights, Queens, that has clearly been abandoned. body: AROUND TOWN MARTIN LUTHER KING'S BIRTHDAY The older a holiday is, the more ingrained its traditions. title: Spare Times Listings

title: Spare Times: For Children
